variant.question: What is the technical term for an increase in temperature with altitude?

options.text: correspond to the dry adiabatic lapse rate.
always change toward a more stable position.
at first coincide with the average dry adiabatic lapse rate and then coincide with the average saturated adiabatic lapse rate.
coincide with the average saturated adiabatic lapse rate in the layer.

variant.question: How does temperature vary with increasing altitude in the ICAO standard atmosphere below the tropopause?

options.text: At first it increases and higher up it decreases.

the presence of warm air above cold terrain.

variant.question: A rising parcel of air which has no heat entering or leaving it, will:

options.text: reduce in pressure, decrease in density, increase in volume.
reduce in pressure, rise in temperature, decrease in density.
maintain volume, decrease in density, reduce in pressure.
maintain pressure, reduce in density, increase in volume.

variant.question: If an orographic cloud descends down a slope, its temperature increases at..

options.text: a lower rate than in dry air, as evaporation, absorbs heat.
the same rate as if the air mass were dry.
a lower rate than in dry air, as condensation gives out heat.
a higher rate than in dry air, as it gives up latent evaporation heat.

variant.question: If a saturated air mass descends down a slope its temperature increases at

options.text: a lower rate than in dry air, as evaporation absorbs heat.
a higher rate than in dry air, as it gives up latent evaporation heat.
a lower rate than in dry air, as condensation gives out heat.

DALR: Dry Adiabatic Lapse rate 
 ELR: Environmental Lapse rate 
 SALR: Saturated Adiabatic Lapse rateAn isothermal layer may exist when in that layer ___.

options.text: SALR is lower than ELR is lower than DALR.

variant.question: Consider a parcel of air which is moved upwards in the surrounding air by an external force. Which one of the following situations describes instability?

options.text: The parcel tends to gain altitude after being released.
The parcel tends to descend when it is released. It will move to, and maintain an altitude below its original altitude.
The parcel tends to maintain its new altitude after being released.
The parcel tends to return to its original altitude when it is released.

variant.question: Explain the term Dry Adiabatic  Lapse Rate (DALR).

options.text: The DALR is the temperature change when a parcel of dry air rises.  It is approximately 3 degrees C per 1000ft
The DALR is the temperature change when a parcel of dry air rises.  It is approximately 2.5 degrees per 1000ft
The DALR is the temperature change when a parcel of dry air rises.  It is approximately 1 degree per 3000ft
The DALR is the temperature change when a parcel of dry air rises.  It is approximately 1.8 degrees per 1000ft

variant.question: Consider a parcel of air being forced upwards in the atmosphere. The lapse rate of the surrounding air is less than the saturated adiabatic lapse rate. After the initial force is no longer effective, the parcel of air will:

options.text: tend to descend to its original altitude.
tend to remain at the new altitude.

water vapour absorbs the incoming heat from the sun

moist air is heavier than dry air

options.text: heat is released during the condensation process.
moist air is heavier than dry air.
water vapor doesn't cool as rapidly as dry air.
water vapor absorbs the incoming heat from the sun.

variant.question: A parcel of unsaturated air is forced to rise through an isothermal layer. So long as it remains unsaturated, the temperature of the parcel...

options.text: becomes equal to the temperature of the isothermal layer

environmental lapse rate is greater than saturated adiabatic lapse rate but less than dry adiabatic lapse rate.
dry adiabatic lapse rate is less than saturated adiabatic lapse rate but greater than environmental lapse rate.

1. The cooling of air by advection over a cooler surface is the result of an adiabatic process

options.text: remains constant while the temperature decreases.
increases while the temperature remains constant.

variant.question: A saturated air parcel is rising, when it cools to below its dew point, it becomes (1) _____, which results in (2) _____.
How does relative humidity and the dew point in an unsaturated air mass change with varying temperature?

options.text: When temperature increases, the relative humidity decreases, and the dew point remains constant.
When temperature increases, the relative humidity increases, and the dew point decreases.
When temperature decreases, the relative humidity decreases, and the dew point increases.
When temperature decreases, the relative humidity and the dew point remain constant.

variant.question: In the lower levels of the atmosphere when the environmental lapse rate is greater than saturated adiabatic lapse rate but less than dry adiabatic lapse rate, the air mass is described as being:

When a mass of unsaturated air descends, what effect will it have on relative humidity?

options.text: It increases up to 100%, then remains stable.

variant.question: Adiabatic cooling is the decrease in temperature..

options.text: of an expanding volume of air without heat exchange with its surroundings.
of a volume of air gained by the compression of the respective volume.
due to the transfer of latent heat into an adjacent heat sink.
that is best achieved by very slow processes to foster heat exchange.

variant.question: Which statement is correct for an absolutely unstable atmosphere?

options.text: The environmental lapse rate is less than 1°C / 100 m
The dry adiabatic lapse rate is more than 1°C / 100 m
Clouds are mainly of the stratiform type

variant.question: Which statement is correct for an absolutely unstable atmosphere?

options.text: The environmental lapse rate is less than 1 °C / 100 m.
Clouds are mainly of the stratiform type.
The dry adiabatic lapse rate is more than 1 °C / 100 m.

options.text: It increases up to 100%, then remains stable.

is between the dry and saturated adiabatic lapse rate.
is less than the saturated adiabatic lapse rate.

options.text: the temperature decreases at a constant rate of 0.65°C/100 m (2°C/1000 ft).

A volume of a parcel of 1m3 of saturated air stays constant
If temperature decreases

the vapour pressure will remain the same.
the relative humidity will decrease as well.

variant.question: A parcel of unsaturated air is lifted to just below the condensation level and then returned to its original level. What is the final temperature of the parcel of air?

options.text: The same as the starting temperature.

 What is the final temperature of the parcel of air?

options.text: The same as the starting temperature.

variant.question: On the tephigram, the green line represents the Dry Adiabatic Lapse Rate because:

options.text: The DALR is a linear decrease in air temperature with altitude at a constant rate.
The dry adiabatic lapse rate is not constant, its approximate lapse rate is 3°C/1000 ft, but it can vary.
The DALR is not linear as latent heat is released, and this is represented accordingly on the tephigram.
The dry adiabatic cooling is not represented by the green line.

variant.question: Define adiabatic cooling:

options.text: Air cools by expanding due to lower ambient pressure without any heat transfer.
Adiabatic cooling occurs only when certain atmospheric conditions are achieved, such as high relative humidity.
The most important factor in adiabatic cooling is the outside air temperature.
Air cools by compressing due to lower ambient pressure without any heat transfer.

variant.question: Define adiabatic cooling:

options.text: stable for unsaturated air and unstable for saturated air.
stable for saturated air and unstable for unsaturated air.
unstable for unsaturated air and conditionally unstable.
unstable for unsaturated air and neutral for saturated air.

variant.question:
Refer to figure.  
  The red line represents the Saturated Adiabatic Lapse Rate on the tephigram because:

options.text: The SALR is not linear as latent heat is released, and this is represented accordingly on the tephigram as a curved line away from the DALR.
The saturated adiabatic cooling is not represented by the red line.
The SALR is a linear decrease in air temperature with altitude at a constant rate.
The saturated adiabatic lapse rate is not constant. It is approximately 3°C/1 000 ft, but it can vary.

variant.question: What is a characteristic phenomenon for a stable atmosphere?
Two unsaturated volumes of air at different temperatures mix. Cloud formation will happen if.

options.text: the combined volume, at the combined temperature, becomes saturated and condensation occurs.
both air masses mix over a very long amount of time so that an adiabatic process is achieved.
there is a reservoir of humidity (such as a lake) nearby that provides for the necessary water droplets.
the temperature difference between the two air masses exceeds 20°C.

options.text: The air is neutral for dry air.

variant.question: What is the main result of the Fohn Effect?

options.text: Warmer and drier conditions on the leeward (downwind) side of the mountain than on the windward (upwind) side.
Warmer and drier conditions on the windward (upwind) side of the mountain than on the leeward (downwind) side.

cold and dry air descending at the leeward side of the Appalachian Mountains.
strong cold wind, mostly observed in the Rhone valley, blowing towards Southern France.
